description: From late Middle English mature, from Middle French mature, from Latin mātūrus. Doublet of maduro. Partially displaced ripe, from Old English rīpe (“ripe, mature”).

adjectives.description: mature (comparative maturer or more mature, superlative maturest or most mature)

entries.meaning: Fully developed; grown up in terms of physical appearance, behaviour or thinking; ripe.
examples: She is quite mature for her age.
The excellent mature eggplants grown in the garden plot are quickly being being picked up by family and friends.

entries.meaning: Brought to a state of complete readiness.

examples: The headmaster decided to expel the boy after a mature consideration.

entries.meaning: (medicine, obsolete) Come to, or in a state of, completed suppuration.
(television, film) Suitable for adults only, due to sexual themes, violence, etc.

description: From Middle English maturen, from Middle French maturer (“to mature”), from Latin mātūrō.

verbs.description: mature (third-person singular simple present matures, present participle maturing, simple past and past participle matured)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To proceed toward maturity: full development or completion (either of concrete or of abstract things, e.g. plans, judgments, qualities).
(intransitive, of food, especially fruit) To attain maturity, to become mature or ripe.
(transitive) To bring (something) to maturity, full development, or completion.
(transitive) To make (something, e.g. fruit) ripe or mature.
(intransitive, of a person) To proceed toward or become mature or full-grown, either physically or psychologically; to gain experience or wisdom with age.
examples: Synonyms: age, develop, grow up; see also Thesaurus:to age

entries.meaning: (intransitive, finance) To reach the date when payment is due.
examples: When the bond matures, the full face value is payable to its bearer.
